title: Acts Chapter 14 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 14 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 14 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 14.

questions.question: In which city did Paul and Barnabas first speak boldly in the synagogue, causing many Jews and Greeks to believe?
options: Iconium
Lystra
Derbe
Antioch
questions.correctAnswer: Iconium
questions.explanation: Acts 14:1 states that Paul and Barnabas went into the synagogue in Iconium and spoke so that a great multitude believed.

questions.question: Who stirred up the Gentiles against the brethren in Iconium?
options: Unbelieving Jews
The apostles
The rulers
The Greeks
questions.correctAnswer: Unbelieving Jews
questions.explanation: Acts 14:2 explains that the unbelieving Jews stirred up the Gentiles to have evil minds against the brethren.

questions.question: True or False: According to Acts 14:3, Paul and Barnabas performed signs and wonders by their hands to testify to the word of God's grace.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 14:3 says the Lord gave testimony unto the word of his grace and granted signs and wonders by their hands.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the city’s people to Paul and Barnabas in Iconium?
options: The city was divided
Everyone believed
They were all hostile
They ignored them
questions.correctAnswer: The city was divided
questions.explanation: Acts 14:4 states that the multitude of the city was divided, with some siding with the Jews and some with the apostles.

questions.question: When threatened with stoning, to which cities did Paul and Barnabas flee?
options: Lystra and Derbe
Antioch and Iconium
Perga and Attalia
Pamphylia and Pisidia
questions.correctAnswer: Lystra and Derbe
questions.explanation: Acts 14:6 states they fled to Lystra and Derbe after learning of the assault.

questions.question: Who was the man in Lystra that Paul healed?
options: A cripple from birth
A blind man
A deaf man
A mute man
questions.correctAnswer: A cripple from birth
questions.explanation: Acts 14:8 describes a man impotent in his feet, crippled from his mother's womb, whom Paul healed.

questions.question: What did the people of Lystra call Barnabas and Paul after the healing miracle?
options: Jupiter and Mercurius
Zeus and Hermes
Apollo and Ares
Poseidon and Hermes
questions.correctAnswer: Jupiter and Mercurius
questions.explanation: Acts 14:12 says Barnabas was called Jupiter and Paul Mercurius because he was the chief speaker.

questions.question: True or False: The apostles accepted the people's attempt to offer sacrifices to them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 14:14 shows the apostles rent their clothes and stopped the people from offering sacrifices.

questions.question: Complete the statement from Acts 14:15: 'We also are men of like ______ with you.'
options: passions
sins
strength
faith
questions.correctAnswer: passions
questions.explanation: Acts 14:15 says, 'We also are men of like passions with you,' indicating their humanity.

questions.question: What reason did Paul give to the people for turning from their idols to the living God?
options: He made heaven, earth, sea, and all things
He gave them wealth
He was a god from heaven
He performed miracles for them
questions.correctAnswer: He made heaven, earth, sea, and all things
questions.explanation: Acts 14:15 explains that God made heaven, earth, sea, and all things therein.

questions.question: What did God provide to the people as a witness according to Acts 14:17?
options: Rain from heaven and fruitful seasons
Wealth and power
Miracles and signs
Prophets and angels
questions.correctAnswer: Rain from heaven and fruitful seasons
questions.explanation: Acts 14:17 says God gave rain and fruitful seasons to fill hearts with food and gladness.

questions.question: True or False: Paul was stoned and left for dead but later recovered and continued his journey.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 14:19-20 describes Paul being stoned, presumed dead, but he rose and continued on.

questions.question: What did Paul and Barnabas do when they returned to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch after preaching in Derbe?
options: Confirmed the disciples and exhorted them to continue in faith
Built new synagogues
Fled to another city
Held a feast
questions.correctAnswer: Confirmed the disciples and exhorted them to continue in faith
questions.explanation: Acts 14:21-22 recounts that they confirmed the souls of the disciples and exhorted them to continue in faith.

questions.question: Where did Paul and Barnabas ordain elders and pray with fasting before commending them to the Lord?
options: In every church
Only in Lystra
In Antioch alone
In Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: In every church
questions.explanation: Acts 14:23 states they ordained elders in every church and prayed with fasting.

questions.question: Where did Paul and Barnabas sail to after Perga and Attalia?
options: Antioch
Jerusalem
Rome
Corinth
questions.correctAnswer: Antioch
questions.explanation: Acts 14:26 says they sailed to Antioch after preaching in Perga and going down to Attalia.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 14 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 14 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Acts 14 teach us about perseverance through trials when facing opposition in ministry?
options: Continue boldly preaching despite threats and attacks
Stop preaching to avoid conflict
Only preach to those who agree with you
Avoid dangerous places
questions.correctAnswer: Continue boldly preaching despite threats and attacks
questions.explanation: Acts 14:3 shows Paul and Barnabas speaking boldly in the Lord despite opposition, and Acts 14:5-6 describes attacks against them which they escaped and continued their work. This exemplifies perseverance through trials.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with doubt after being rejected by others for their faith. Based on Acts 14, what encouragement can you offer?
options: God grants signs and wonders to confirm His word
Doubt is a sign to quit faith
Only the strong will be accepted
God will remove all difficulties immediately
questions.correctAnswer: God grants signs and wonders to confirm His word
questions.explanation: Acts 14:3 mentions that the Lord gave testimony to the word of His grace by granting signs and wonders, encouraging believers to trust God’s confirmation even in opposition.

questions.question: How does Acts 14 exemplify the importance of evangelism and sharing the Gospel with both Jews and Gentiles?
options: They preached in synagogues to Jews and in cities to Gentiles
They preached only to Jews
They avoided Gentiles entirely
They only preached after many years
questions.correctAnswer: They preached in synagogues to Jews and in cities to Gentiles
questions.explanation: Acts 14:1 shows preaching in the synagogue where Jews and Greeks believed; Acts 14:7 shows preaching in cities like Lystra and Derbe, demonstrating outreach to diverse groups.

questions.question: What biblical truth about humility can be learned from Paul and Barnabas’ reaction to being mistakenly worshipped as gods?
options: They corrected the people and emphasized they are men like them
They accepted the worship to gain popularity
They ignored the people
They claimed they were gods
questions.correctAnswer: They corrected the people and emphasized they are men like them
questions.explanation: Acts 14:14-15 shows Paul and Barnabas tearing their clothes and explaining they are men with like passions, urging people to worship the living God instead, demonstrating humility and honesty.

questions.question: According to Acts 14, what role does prayer and fasting play in church leadership and community life?
options: They prayed and fasted before ordaining elders
They never prayed before decisions
Fasting was discouraged
Leaders were chosen randomly
questions.correctAnswer: They prayed and fasted before ordaining elders
questions.explanation: Acts 14:23 states that Paul and Barnabas prayed with fasting when ordaining elders, illustrating the importance of spiritual discipline in leadership decisions.

questions.question: How does Acts 14 encourage believers to continue in faith during trials and tribulations?
options: We must through much tribulation enter the kingdom of God
Trials mean God has abandoned us
Faith should be abandoned in hardships
Only the perfect avoid tribulation
questions.correctAnswer: We must through much tribulation enter the kingdom of God
questions.explanation: Acts 14:22 exhorts believers to continue in faith, knowing tribulation is part of the journey into God’s kingdom, encouraging perseverance.

questions.question: What practical lesson about sharing God’s grace with others can we learn from Paul and Barnabas returning to Antioch and reporting their work?
options: They gathered the church and rehearsed all God had done
They kept their work secret
They only shared with close friends
They avoided discussing the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: They gathered the church and rehearsed all God had done
questions.explanation: Acts 14:27 shows Paul and Barnabas sharing openly about God’s work and the opening of faith to Gentiles, encouraging transparency and fellowship in the church.

questions.question: True or False: According to Acts 14, Paul was stoned and left for dead but then miraculously recovered and continued his mission.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 14:19-20 describes how Paul was stoned and drawn out of the city, supposed dead, but he rose up and continued his work, demonstrating God’s sustaining power.

questions.question: True or False: Paul and Barnabas accepted being called gods by the Lystran people without correction.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 14:14-15 shows they rent their clothes and strongly corrected the people, emphasizing they were men like them and directing worship to God alone.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Paul and Barnabas told the people to turn from these _____ unto the living God.
options: vanities
sins
idols
falsehoods
questions.correctAnswer: vanities
questions.explanation: Acts 14:15 uses the term 'vanities' to describe what the people were worshipping, urging them to turn to the living God instead.

questions.question: How does Acts 14 demonstrate the importance of faith in healing and miracles?
options: Paul perceived the man had faith to be healed and commanded him to stand
Healing happened randomly without faith
Faith was not necessary for miracles
Only Barnabas prayed for healing
questions.correctAnswer: Paul perceived the man had faith to be healed and commanded him to stand
questions.explanation: Acts 14:9-10 shows Paul looking intently and perceiving the man's faith before healing him, highlighting the role of faith in God’s miraculous work.

questions.question: What does Acts 14 teach about the importance of confirming and encouraging new believers?
options: They confirmed the souls of disciples and exhorted them to continue in faith
They left new believers to fend for themselves
They discouraged new believers from attending church
They only taught mature believers
questions.correctAnswer: They confirmed the souls of disciples and exhorted them to continue in faith
questions.explanation: Acts 14:22 describes Paul and Barnabas strengthening new believers and encouraging perseverance, emphasizing care and discipleship.

questions.question: According to Acts 14, what can we learn about God’s providence in creation and daily life?
options: God made heaven, earth, sea, and all things and gives rain and fruitful seasons
God only cares about spiritual matters
Creation happened by chance
God does not provide for physical needs
questions.correctAnswer: God made heaven, earth, sea, and all things and gives rain and fruitful seasons
questions.explanation: Acts 14:15-17 teaches that God is the Creator who sustains life with rain and fruitful seasons, showing His providential care.

questions.question: How does Acts 14 illustrate the value of teamwork and partnership in Christian ministry?
options: Paul and Barnabas traveled and preached together supporting each other
Ministers should work alone
Only one leader is necessary per church
Partnership is discouraged
questions.correctAnswer: Paul and Barnabas traveled and preached together supporting each other
questions.explanation: Throughout Acts 14 (e.g., verses 1, 14, 20), Paul and Barnabas are seen working jointly, showing the strength of partnership in ministry.

questions.question: What does Acts 14 teach about responding to false accusations or opposition from others?
options: Flee when necessary but continue preaching the Gospel
Retaliate aggressively
Give up ministry
Ignore the opposition completely
questions.correctAnswer: Flee when necessary but continue preaching the Gospel
questions.explanation: Acts 14:5-6 shows they fled from danger but immediately continued preaching in other cities, balancing prudence and obedience.

hard.title: Acts Chapter 14 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 14.

questions.question: In Acts 14:1, what was significant about the audience that Paul and Barnabas addressed in the synagogue at Iconium?
options: Both Jews and Greeks believed
Only Jews believed
Only Greeks believed
No one believed
questions.correctAnswer: Both Jews and Greeks believed
questions.explanation: Acts 14:1 states that a great multitude both of the Jews and also of the Greeks believed when Paul and Barnabas spoke in the synagogue.

questions.question: What type of opposition did the unbelieving Jews stir up against the brethren according to Acts 14:2?
options: They made the Gentiles hostile towards them
They physically attacked the apostles immediately
They ignored the apostles' preaching
They supported the apostles secretly
questions.correctAnswer: They made the Gentiles hostile towards them
questions.explanation: Acts 14:2 describes how the unbelieving Jews stirred up the Gentiles and made their minds evil affected against the brethren, inciting hostility.

questions.question: How did Paul and Barnabas respond to the threat of being stoned in Iconium as described in Acts 14:6?
options: They fled to Lystra and Derbe
They stayed and defended themselves
They called for Roman protection
They ceased preaching altogether
questions.correctAnswer: They fled to Lystra and Derbe
questions.explanation: Acts 14:6 tells that Paul and Barnabas, aware of the assault planned against them, fled to the cities of Lystra and Derbe.

questions.question: The healing of the crippled man in Lystra (Acts 14:8-10) is an example of what literary device commonly used in Acts?
options: Typology foreshadowing Christ's power
Parable illustrating faith
A metaphor for spiritual blindness
An allegory for salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Typology foreshadowing Christ's power
questions.explanation: The healing miracle performed by Paul in Lystra foreshadows the healing power of Christ and confirms apostolic authority, a typological device seen throughout Acts (Acts 14:8-10).

questions.question: What cultural misunderstanding is revealed by the reaction of the Lystrans after the healing miracle in Acts 14:11-13?
options: They thought Paul and Barnabas were gods
They assumed the apostles were magicians
They believed the healing was a trick
They saw the apostles as Roman officials
questions.correctAnswer: They thought Paul and Barnabas were gods
questions.explanation: The people of Lycaonia called Barnabas Jupiter and Paul Mercurius, interpreting the miracle as a divine visitation of gods in human form (Acts 14:11-13).

questions.question: How did Paul and Barnabas respond to the people’s attempt to offer sacrifices to them in Acts 14:14-15?
options: They tore their clothes and urged people to worship the living God
They accepted the sacrifices briefly
They ignored the people and continued preaching
They called Roman authorities to stop the worship
questions.correctAnswer: They tore their clothes and urged people to worship the living God
questions.explanation: Paul and Barnabas rent their clothes and ran among the people, urging them to cease idolatry and turn to the living God who created all things (Acts 14:14-15).

questions.question: The phrase 'living God' in Acts 14:15 connects to which Old Testament theological theme?
options: The Creator God of Genesis who sustains all life
The golden calf worship in Exodus
The Baal worship condemned in Judges
The silent God of Ecclesiastes
questions.correctAnswer: The Creator God of Genesis who sustains all life
questions.explanation: Acts 14:15 refers to the living God who made heaven, earth, sea, and all things, echoing Genesis 1 where God is the Creator of all.

questions.question: What evidence does Paul give in Acts 14:16-17 to show that God has not left Himself without witness among the nations?
options: God did good, gave rain, fruitful seasons, and filled hearts with food and gladness
God sent angels to guide the nations daily
God wrote the law on every nation’s hearts
God caused earthquakes to humble the nations
questions.correctAnswer: God did good, gave rain, fruitful seasons, and filled hearts with food and gladness
questions.explanation: Acts 14:17 explains that God's goodness is witnessed by providing rain, fruitful seasons, and food, showing His care even to those walking in their own ways.

questions.question: What typological significance does Paul’s stoning in Acts 14:19 hold in the broader New Testament narrative?
options: It foreshadows the suffering and resurrection motif central to Christ and the apostles
It symbolizes the rejection of the Law in favor of grace
It represents the fall of Jerusalem in AD 70
It prefigures the destruction of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the suffering and resurrection motif central to Christ and the apostles
questions.explanation: Paul’s stoning and subsequent resurrection (Acts 14:19-20) typologically parallels Christ’s death and resurrection, emphasizing apostolic suffering and victory.

questions.question: After healing and facing persecution, what was the primary mission focus of Paul and Barnabas as they traveled to Derbe and beyond in Acts 14:21-23?
options: Preaching the gospel, teaching many, confirming disciples, and ordaining elders
Establishing Roman legal authority
Collecting funds for the Jerusalem church
Planning a military rebellion against local rulers
questions.correctAnswer: Preaching the gospel, teaching many, confirming disciples, and ordaining elders
questions.explanation: Acts 14:21-23 records that Paul and Barnabas preached, taught, strengthened disciples, and appointed elders in every church, focusing on church planting and leadership.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God' in Acts 14:22 reveal about early Christian theology?
options: Suffering is a necessary part of discipleship and entering God’s kingdom
Only the wealthy can enter the kingdom of God
Faith alone guarantees immediate earthly prosperity
The kingdom of God will be established without hardship
questions.correctAnswer: Suffering is a necessary part of discipleship and entering God’s kingdom
questions.explanation: Acts 14:22 emphasizes that believers must endure tribulation, indicating suffering as integral to the Christian journey toward God’s kingdom.

questions.question: Which cities did Paul and Barnabas revisit to strengthen the churches before traveling to Pamphylia and Perga, according to Acts 14:21 and 24-25?
options: Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch
Jerusalem, Damascus, and Tarsus
Ephesus, Corinth, and Philippi
Rome, Athens, and Thessalonica
questions.correctAnswer: Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch
questions.explanation: Acts 14:21 and 24-25 indicate that Paul and Barnabas returned to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch before passing through Pisidia and Pamphylia.

questions.question: What does the term 'elders' ordained in every church in Acts 14:23 imply about the early Christian community structure?
options: A formal leadership role responsible for guidance and oversight
A purely symbolic title with no real authority
A political office within Roman government
A designation for traveling missionaries only
questions.correctAnswer: A formal leadership role responsible for guidance and oversight
questions.explanation: Acts 14:23 describes the ordination of elders, indicating early church governance involved appointed leaders for spiritual oversight.

questions.question: True or False: According to Acts 14:27, Paul and Barnabas reported that God had opened the door of faith only to the Jewish people.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 14:27 explicitly states that God had opened the door of faith to the Gentiles, highlighting the expansion of the gospel beyond the Jewish community.

questions.question: According to Acts 14:26, what was the significance of Paul and Barnabas sailing back to Antioch?
options: It was the place from which they were recommended to the grace of God for their mission
It was the capital of the Roman Empire
It was where they planned to establish a new temple
It was the location of the Jerusalem council
questions.correctAnswer: It was the place from which they were recommended to the grace of God for their mission
questions.explanation: Acts 14:26 notes Antioch as the city that had initially recommended Paul and Barnabas to God's grace for their missionary work, marking it as their sending church.

theological.title: Acts Chapter 14 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 14 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Acts 14, what was the primary reason Paul and Barnabas fled from Iconium to Lystra and Derbe?
options: Because of an assault by Gentiles and Jews intending to stone them
Because they had completed their mission in Iconium
Because they wanted to preach to new cities
Because they were called to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Because of an assault by Gentiles and Jews intending to stone them
questions.explanation: Acts 14:5-6 show that there was an assault made by both Gentiles and Jews with their rulers to stone Paul and Barnabas, so they fled to Lystra and Derbe. This reflects the opposition to the gospel found also in Acts 9:23-25, 2 Corinthians 11:24-27, and Matthew 10:16-23.

questions.question: What significant miracle did Paul perform in Lystra that caused the people to believe they were gods?
options: He healed a man crippled from birth, enabling him to walk
He raised a man from the dead
He cast out an evil spirit
He multiplied food to feed the crowd
questions.correctAnswer: He healed a man crippled from birth, enabling him to walk
questions.explanation: Acts 14:8-10 describes Paul healing a man crippled from birth who had never walked. This miracle led the people to think the gods had come down in human form, illustrating the power of God working through the apostles. This aligns with Old Testament healing miracles like those of Elijah (1 Kings 17:17-24) and Elisha (2 Kings 4:32-37), and Christ's healing ministry (Luke 5:17-26).

questions.question: How did Paul and Barnabas respond when the people of Lystra tried to worship them as gods?
options: They tore their clothes and urged the people to worship the living God
They accepted the worship and received sacrifices
They fled the city immediately
They performed more miracles to prove their divinity
questions.correctAnswer: They tore their clothes and urged the people to worship the living God
questions.explanation: Acts 14:14-15 records that Paul and Barnabas tore their clothes—a sign of distress—and pleaded with the people to turn from idolatry to the living God, the Creator. This reflects the biblical teaching against idolatry seen in Exodus 20:3-5, Deuteronomy 5:7-9, and Paul's later teaching in 1 Corinthians 8:4-6.

questions.question: According to Acts 14, what is one attribute of God emphasized by Paul when addressing the people in Lystra?
options: God is the Creator of heaven, earth, sea, and all things within them
God is a distant deity uninvolved in human affairs
God only reveals Himself through angels
God primarily judges nations without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: God is the Creator of heaven, earth, sea, and all things within them
questions.explanation: In Acts 14:15, Paul describes God as the living Creator of all things, emphasizing His sovereignty and power over creation. This connects with Genesis 1:1, Psalm 33:6-9, Isaiah 40:28, and John 1:3, affirming God's role as Creator and Sustainer of all life.

questions.question: What theological truth about human sin and divine patience is expressed in Acts 14:16-17?
options: God allowed nations to walk in their own ways but did not leave Himself without witness
God immediately judged all nations without delay
Humans are incapable of turning to God without visible miracles
God's blessings are earned by human works
questions.correctAnswer: God allowed nations to walk in their own ways but did not leave Himself without witness
questions.explanation: Acts 14:16-17 teaches that God permitted nations to follow their sinful paths yet still provided testimony of Himself through blessings like rain and fruitful seasons. This shows God’s longsuffering and common grace, consistent with Psalm 145:9, Romans 2:4, Jonah 4:2, and Matthew 5:45.

questions.question: What does Acts 14:22 teach about the nature of the Christian life in relation to salvation and the kingdom of God?
options: Believers must endure much tribulation to enter the kingdom of God
Salvation is guaranteed without any trials or suffering
Faith is based solely on human effort and works
The kingdom of God is only for the Jewish people
questions.correctAnswer: Believers must endure much tribulation to enter the kingdom of God
questions.explanation: Acts 14:22 exhorts believers to remain steadfast in faith despite suffering, teaching that entering God’s kingdom involves persevering through trials. This aligns with teachings in John 16:33, James 1:2-4, 1 Peter 4:12-13, and Romans 5:3-5 about the refining nature of suffering in Christian growth.

questions.question: What ecclesiological practice is described in Acts 14:23 regarding the early church leadership?
options: Paul and Barnabas ordained elders in every church and prayed with fasting
They appointed deacons to oversee finances only
They left leadership to be determined by the Roman authorities
They discouraged formal church leadership structures
questions.correctAnswer: Paul and Barnabas ordained elders in every church and prayed with fasting
questions.explanation: Acts 14:23 describes the appointment of elders in the churches, accompanied by prayer and fasting, highlighting the biblical pattern of qualified leadership (Titus 1:5-9; 1 Timothy 3:1-7) and dependence on the Holy Spirit. This practice affirms the importance of spiritual oversight and pastoral care in the church.

questions.question: How does Acts 14:27 contribute to the understanding of the gospel's expansion to the Gentiles?
options: It reports that God opened the door of faith to the Gentiles through the apostles' ministry
It states that the gospel was only for the Jews in Antioch
It emphasizes that Gentiles must first become Jews to be saved
It says that the Gentiles rejected the gospel entirely
questions.correctAnswer: It reports that God opened the door of faith to the Gentiles through the apostles' ministry
questions.explanation: Acts 14:27 shows the early church recognizing God's sovereign work in bringing Gentiles to faith, supporting the biblical theme of salvation for all peoples (Isaiah 49:6, Romans 1:16, Galatians 3:28, Ephesians 3:6). This verse underscores the inclusiveness of the gospel message.

questions.question: What role does faith play in the healing miracle performed by Paul in Lystra as described in Acts 14:9-10?
options: Paul perceived that the man had faith to be healed
Faith was unnecessary because of the miracle
The man was healed by the crowd's faith
Paul healed the man without regard to faith
questions.correctAnswer: Paul perceived that the man had faith to be healed
questions.explanation: Acts 14:9 reveals that Paul, by steadfastly looking at the man, perceived his faith as a condition for healing. This highlights the biblical principle that faith is integral to receiving God's healing (Mark 5:34, Luke 17:19, Hebrews 11:6, James 5:15).

questions.question: What does the reaction of the people in Lystra to the healing miracle reveal about human tendencies addressed in biblical apologetics?
options: People tend to idolize the messenger rather than God
People always recognize God's work immediately
People reject miracles as deceitful
People only believe after extensive teaching
questions.correctAnswer: People tend to idolize the messenger rather than God
questions.explanation: Acts 14:11-13 shows that the people called Barnabas and Paul gods and sought to offer sacrifices to them, illustrating a common human tendency to misdirect worship. This tendency is addressed in biblical apologetics through the call to worship the one true God (Exodus 20:3-5, Romans 1:21-25, 1 Corinthians 10:14, Colossians 2:18).

questions.question: What is the significance of Paul’s resurrection after being stoned in Lystra, as described in Acts 14:19-20, in the context of Christological testimony?
options: It affirms the power of God to give life and vindicate His servants
It shows that Paul was divine like Jesus
It indicates that the apostles were immune to death
It suggests that physical resurrection was common in the early church
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms the power of God to give life and vindicate His servants
questions.explanation: Acts 14:19-20 reports Paul’s miraculous survival and recovery after being stoned, reinforcing the biblical truth of God’s power over death, foreshadowing Christ’s resurrection (Romans 6:4-5, 1 Corinthians 15:20-22, Philippians 3:10, 2 Timothy 4:18). This vindicates Paul’s apostolic authority and God's sustaining grace.

questions.question: According to Acts 14:1-4, how did the population of Iconium react to the preaching of Paul and Barnabas?
options: The city was divided, with some siding with the Jews and others with the apostles
Everyone accepted the gospel without opposition
The apostles were immediately expelled from the city
Only the Gentiles believed, while all Jews rejected the message
questions.correctAnswer: The city was divided, with some siding with the Jews and others with the apostles
questions.explanation: Acts 14:1-4 highlights that the response in Iconium was mixed, causing division among the people. This division is typical in gospel history (John 7:43, Matthew 10:34-36, Luke 12:51-53, 1 Corinthians 1:18-25) and reflects the ongoing conflict between belief and unbelief.

questions.question: What does Acts 14:3 indicate about the role of signs and wonders in the early Christian mission?
options: God granted signs and wonders to confirm the word of His grace
Signs and wonders were performed to entertain crowds
Miracles replaced the need for preaching
Signs and wonders were done by the crowd themselves
questions.correctAnswer: God granted signs and wonders to confirm the word of His grace
questions.explanation: Acts 14:3 states that God bore witness to His word by granting signs and wonders through the apostles, confirming the gospel message. This is consistent with biblical accounts of miracles confirming divine authority (Hebrews 2:3-4, Mark 16:17-20, John 20:30-31, Exodus 4:1-9).

questions.question: In Acts 14:15-17, Paul appeals to the living God who made heaven and earth. How does this connect to the doctrine of natural revelation?
options: God’s existence and attributes are evident in creation and common grace
God only reveals Himself through Scripture, not creation
Natural revelation is insufficient for salvation
Humans can fully know God without any revelation
questions.correctAnswer: God’s existence and attributes are evident in creation and common grace
questions.explanation: Paul's appeal to creation (Acts 14:15-17) demonstrates natural revelation, where God's invisible qualities and providential acts are perceived through the created order (Romans 1:18-20, Psalm 19:1-4, Job 12:7-10, Acts 17:24-28). This lays a foundation for apologetics and evangelism.

questions.question: What does Acts 14:26-28 reveal about the importance of testimony and community in the early church?
options: Paul and Barnabas gathered the church and reported all that God had done through them
They avoided sharing their experiences to remain humble
They focused only on individual conversions without community
They returned without informing the church of their mission
questions.correctAnswer: Paul and Barnabas gathered the church and reported all that God had done through them
questions.explanation: In Acts 14:26-28, the apostles' gathering and sharing testimony with the church highlights the biblical principle of communal encouragement and accountability (Hebrews 10:24-25, 1 Thessalonians 5:11, Revelation 12:11, Acts 2:42). Testimony strengthens faith and fosters unity.
